aws::graph::propositions: # Helicopter Accident Report Details
The accident occurred at coordinates 42.176666, -91.980834 (estimated).
The weather conditions included wind from 240 degrees at 3 knots.
The weather conditions included 10 miles visibility.
The weather conditions included clear skies.
The weather conditions included temperature of 27°C.
The weather conditions included dew point of 22°C.
The weather conditions included barometric pressure of 29.89 inches of mercury.
The pilot reported variable wind favoring 180 degrees at 3-5 knots.
The accident resulted in no injuries to the crew.
The accident involved 1 crew member.
The accident did not involve any passengers.
There were no ground injuries in the accident.
The total injury count was 1 None.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There was no aircraft fire.
There was no aircraft explosion.
The helicopter came to rest upright in a bean field.
The main rotor blades sustained damage from ground impact.
The tail rotor blades sustained damage from ground impact.
The tail boom was separated from the helicopter.
A post-accident examination did not reveal any mechanical malfunctions with the airframe.
A post-accident examination did not reveal any mechanical malfunctions with the engine.
A post-accident examination did not reveal any failures that would have precluded normal operation.
The flight was being recorded by a hand-held recording device.
The video footage showed the pilot flew the helicopter off a truck bed.
The video footage showed the helicopter flew about 50 yards while maintaining an altitude of about 10 feet above the ground.
The video footage showed the helicopter landed in tall grass after the initial flight.
The video footage showed the helicopter lifted off again after the initial landing.
The video footage showed the helicopter flew over a bean field for about 100 yards during the second flight.
The video footage showed the helicopter descended during the second flight.
The pilot executed a forced landing straight ahead in the bean field.
The helicopter struck the ground with the tail low.
The tail-low impact resulted in damage to the tail boom and tail rotor.
Scott's Helicopter Services is the helicopter's type-certificate holder.
Scott's Helicopter Services was a party to the investigation.
A representative of Scott's Helicopter Services reviewed the video footage.
The representative noted the pilot should have assessed the weight and balance when the helicopter first settled in the grass.
The representative noted the pilot possibly should have off-loaded applicant when the helicopter first settled in the grass.
The representative noted the pilot did not fly along the road during the second attempt.
The representative noted the pilot chose a flight path over standing crops during the second attempt.
The engine sounds were normal during the takeoff.
The engine later sounded as though it was "lugged down" as the takeoff continued.

text:
# Accident Report

## Accident Details

- Location: 42.176666, -91.980834 (estimated)
- Wind: 240 degrees at 3 knots, 10 miles visibility, clear skies, temperature 27°C, dew point 22°C, barometric pressure 29.89 inches of mercury
- Pilot reported variable wind favoring 180 degrees at 3-5 knots

## Wreckage and Impact Information

| Category | Details |
| --- | --- |
| Crew Injuries | 1 None |
| Passenger Injuries | N/A |
| Ground Injuries | N/A |
| Total Injuries | 1 None |
| Aircraft Damage | Substantial |
| Aircraft Fire | None |
| Aircraft Explosion | None |
| Latitude, Longitude | 42.176666, -91.980834 (estimated) |

The helicopter came to rest upright in a bean field. The main rotor blades and tail rotor blades impacted the ground and sustained damage. The tail boom was separated from the helicopter. A post-accident examination did not reveal any mechanical malfunctions or failures with the airframe or engine that would have precluded normal operation.

## Additional Information

### Video Footage

The flight was being recorded by a hand-held recording device. The video footage revealed that the pilot flew the helicopter off the truck bed, flew about 50 yards while maintaining an altitude of about 10 feet above the ground (AGL), and then landed in tall grass. Shortly after, the helicopter lifted off again and flew over a bean field for about 100 yards. The helicopter descended and the pilot executed a forced landing straight ahead in the bean field. The helicopter struck the ground with the tail low, which resulted in damage to the tail boom and tail rotor.

The video footage was reviewed by a representative of Scott's Helicopter Services, the helicopter's type-certificate holder and a party to the investigation. He noted that when the helicopter first settled in the grass, the pilot should have assessed the weight and balance and possibly off-loaded applicant. The flight path of the second attempt, the pilot did not fly along the road, but chose a flight path over standing crops. The engine sounds were normal during the takeoff but then sounded as though the engine was "lugged down" as the takeoff continued.
